ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

JOINT INDUSTRIAL TRAINING CENTRES


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health what type of industrial training will be provided at the different Joint Industrial Training Centres, and whether any of these Centres will be located at Ang Mo Kio New Town.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, the Economic Development Board runs four Joint Industrial Training Centres. They are:

    (1) Tata-Government Training Centre at Chin Bee Drive, Jurong;

    (2) Philips-Government Training Centre at Jalan Ahmad Ibrahim, Jurong;

    (3) Rollei-Government Training Centre at Kallang Junction: and

    (4) Japan-Singapore Training Centre at Jalan Bukit Merah. These centres provide a four-year apprenticeship training in the following 11 trades designed to meet the needs of industrial firms using advanced skills and technology:-

    (1) Precision Metal Machinery

    (2) Precision Mechanics

    (3) Precision Optics

    (4) Tool and Die Making

    (5) Tool and Die Making (Plastic Moulds)

    (6) Auto-Lathe Setting

    (7) Consumer Electronics

    (8) Industrial Electronics

    (9) Electrical Engineering

    (10) Instrumentation and Control

    (11) Industrial Machinery Maintenance.

    All trainees are required to undergo two years of in-centre training in one of the four training centres and another two years of in-plant attachment in an industrial firm. On

Column: 1088

completion, a trainee will be awarded a trade certificate and will be required to serve a bond with the firm in which he was earlier a"ached. The bond is one year for a trainee who has completed his National Service and three years for a female trainee and male trainee who has not done his full-time National Service.

    The Economic Development Board is also setting up three more training institutes. They are: (1) the Japan-Singapore Institute of Software Technology for programmers and systems analysts at the World Trade Centre; (2) the German-Singapore Institute for production engineering technicians and vocational instructors at Science Centre Road, Jurong; and (3) the French-Singapore Institute for electronics technicians at Science Centre Road, Jurong.

    None of the EDB's training centres and institutes will be located in the Ang Mo Kio New Town. The EDB will, however, consider Ang Mo Kio as a possible location for future training centres. The VITB, whose vocational institutes complement EDB's training centres, has chosen the site at the junction of Ang Mo Kio Avenue 5 and the proposed Sembawang Expressway for its latest vocational institute.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are plans to set up three overseas trade offices in Belgium, Saudi Arabia and the People's Republic of China in financial year 1981-82.

Column: 1089



    Our local industrialists or traders can get assistance from these overseas trade offices, whose function is to promote our exports in overseas markets. Our overseas offices will, therefore, service trade enquiries, seek out foreign buyers and provide logistics support for overseas promotional projects such as organisation of trade fairs and trade missions. Actual follow-up of contacts established and business enquiries received will, however, have to be undertaken by the industrialists and traders themselves.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head I be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead IA-02 of the Development Estimates*.
*The same amendment also stood in the names of Dr Lau Teik Soon and Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon.


    Sir, the Provisional Mass Rapid Transit Authority was set up through an Act of Parliament sometime last year, and the House has had on many occasions debated in great detail and at great length on the Mass Rapid Transit System, and we have also been getting reports. Sir, I am surprised to see that so many millions of dollars, if my memory is correct, more than $10 million, have already been spent on these feasibility studies of the MRT system. Today this House is asked to approve $7 million for FY 81 where the original total project cost would be $21 million. So this vote is one-third of the total original cost. Sir, since so much money is being spent on feasibility studies, I would

Column: 1090

like to hear from the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour what other forms of studies are required before we come to a firm decision, bearing in mind that there is a report on the all-bus system. I think this matter is of very great interest and is being talked about very much in the last few days, since the announcement by the Ministry of Communications that the SBS will, on the first of next month, increase the fares by 10 cents all round. Sir, if I may, with your indulgence proceed along those lines?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Thank you, Sir. I would like to touch on the hike in bus fare of 10 cents all round from 1st April, as was announced in a statement from the Ministry of Communications last Thursday, 19th March, 1981 and was reported on Friday. Although this has not come as a surprise, because the Minister himself has indicated that if we want to have a more efficient bus service we have to pay more. Nonetheless it is a shock to all bus commuters because of the hefty increase. Ten cents appear to be a small sum of money but it is a lot. This is going to cost the bus commuters a lot and that means more profit for the SBS. Coupled with this, the Communications Ministry in its statement made matters worse by saying that the fares will be further increased later this year, after a more detailed scrutiny of the SBS financial outlook has been carried out. In other words, this is more than a double shock.

    With the first shock it does not seem that the interests of the bus commuters have been taken into consideration by the SBS. The SBS has the sole monopoly, so to speak, of providing public transport. It is not cheap. They have been able to give convincing reasons to the Ministry of Communications for the bus fare increases. I would like to ask of the Minister whether his Ministry has considered the simple fact that a mere 10 cents increase means increasing the profits of SBS?

Column: 1091



     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Increasing losses!

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: I do not know whether the Hon. Minister for Foreign Affairs has studied economics. I did not study economics. If increasing fares means a loss, then I think this House will come tumbling down on him.

     Mr Dhanabalan: It will decrease the loss.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Yes, it will decrease the loss. But I do not think so as I will develop along those lines later. Please be a bit patient. Then who suffers? I have in mind school children whose concession passes will be increased from $9 to $12 in the case of primary school students and $13.50 for secondary school and junior college students, including full-time VITB students. Students in the tertiary institutions would have to pay $25 instead of $18 for their monthly student passes. So one look at the percentage increase means 33 1/3%, 50% and 38.9% respectively. This also means that the lower income group, the thousands of office workers, the labourers and other workers, all will have to pay more by the all round increase of 10 cents.

    But the question is, will they be getting better and more efficient bus services? I would fully support the Hon. Minister's call for SBS to increase its paid-up capital rather than for SBS to merely give all sorts of reasons to justify their fare hikes. The House had debated at great length over the way SBS has been operating with profits being foremost in mind. The SBS is a public company and it does not mean that they can get away with what they want. I hope the Hon. Minister will pay attention to my remarks.

    Talking of efficient service, we have heard of appeals for feeder bus services in Kebun Baru Constituency as well as in Joo Chiat Constituency, and these appeals have not been agreed to I know because I have gone down to Joo Chiat constituency. So I hope the Hon. Minister would ensure that bus commuters will get value for their fare. As far as possible, the SBS should provide the

Column: 1092

necessary public transportation with the least inconvenience to the commuters.

    Finally, Sir, may I also suggest that the next increase be deferred to next year?

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, I would just like to add another voice of dissatisfaction with the way the Government has been procrastinating as far as the MRT system is concerned.

    I get the feeling that there is a consensus of view that the MRT is desirable and that it is even feasible to implement. The Hon. Minister has on many occasions stated that it is all a question of costs. But if there is a consensus that the MRT is desirable and feasible, then implementing the system at a future date will only mean a greater escalation of costs. I think that it would be advisable, therefore, to think in terms of implementing the MRT system as soon as possible. The hon. Member for Punggol has already mentioned the considerable sums of money that have been expended on feasibility studies. I think it is time that a decision was made.

    What I would like to ask the Hon. Minister is whether, in this case as in other cases which we have heard in the House concerning other Ministries, there is a conflict of viewpoints between either the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Communications, or whether there is a conflict of viewpoints between Ministers. What is the real reason for the procrastination? This indecisiveness on the part of Government is untypical of the way in which Government has gone about formulating and implementing policies.
2.45 p.m.

    It could be that the Hon. Minister has to look at an option thrusted upon him, the all-bus system. I recall an answer he gave in this House that even if the all-bus system were to be implemented, it would be viable up to the 1990s. If that is the case, then the period after that would require another consideration of a more viable transport system, which means the question of MRT once again. I

Column: 1093

would like the Hon. Minister to inform the House when and how soon it is possible to come to a firm decision as far as the MRT is concerned.

    May I, with your permission, Sir, deal with the recent increase in bus fares. I agree with what the Member for Punggol has just stated. I think the way in which the Hon. Minister has informed the public of future price increase is in my view akin to a slow-torture. The Minister has informed the public that there will be future increases in bus fares and they will come at, maybe, regular intervals. I wonder whether it would not be better to think in terms of a reasonable increase in bus fares on a longer-term basis than to advise the public that the price increases would be forthcoming at more or less regular intervals.

     The Chairman: Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon is not here. Mr Ho Kah Leong.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)( In Mandarin): Sir, I fully agree with the two hon. Members who have spoken before me. I am wondering why the Government has not yet made any decision on the MRT system. Why should the Government delay its decision? The Minister says that perhaps it is necessary to wait until some new technology has turned up so that the cost involved will be less. But, on the other hand, there is another problem to it, because the longer we delay, material cost, manpower and other building costs will also increase. Has the Minister considered this aspect? Although we may have higher technology available in future, which is an unknown feature, all the other costs will also increase by then. I hope the Government will be able to arrive at a prompt and firm decision.

    On the other question about the increase in bus fares, I agree with the other two Members that it is not quite reasonable. As described by the Member for Punggol, the Singapore Bus Service is a monopoly company and has the protection of the Government. The Government seems to be ensuring that the company should make money. Since

Column: 1094

ours is a free market economy, how are we supposed to do that? Of course, a company either makes money or loses money. But this company is special. Since it is a Government-sponsored company, it must make money. But where does the money come from? Of course, it comes from the people who are at the company's mercy. Since it is a monopoly, the people cannot do very much about it. It is therefore left to the Members here to make their voices heard.

    We would still hope that any increase in the bus fares must be reasonable and convincing. Do not blame everything on oil. There seems to be a general ailment, as in the case of the Public Utilities Board, that when they want to increase their charges they blame it on the increase in the price of oil. Likewise, when the bus company wants to increase its fares, they also put the blame on the increase in oil prices. It may very well be a pretext. I hope the Government will make a careful study of the case and give its reasons for increasing the bus fares and should not claim that because of inefficiency and increasing costs the bus company is now losing money and therefore it must recover by increasing its bus fares, which is not right.

    Yesterday, a constituent came to see me at my meet-the-people session and said that he saw several white-clad bus company staff roaming around the Jurong Town Bus Interchange. They seemed to be walking around aimlessly, with nothing to do. If bus fares are to be increased in order to maintain such seemingly redundant staff on the payroll, I think it is not right nor reasonable. Of course, there could be other areas where the bus company could try to economize, mechanize or automate in order to reduce expenditure and increase productivity.

    The Minister had been to Hong Kong to see for himself the underground railway system. We could well adopt the ticketing system in which train tickets can be obtained from an automatic machine. These tickets can be used many times, thus saving the cost of printing. The passengers board the train with the necessary tickets which will be returned. Thus, no conductor is required and

Column: 1095

the bus can also be driven and controlled by one driver. I mention this just for the reference and consideration of the Minister.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong)( In Mandarin): Sir, I would also like to take part in this debate. On the question of the MRT, I dare say that I was the first Member of Parliament to make an appeal to the Government to proceed with this system. But, unfortunately, the Government has delayed and further delayed the matter. I do not want to go further into the matter except to say that time will prove that what I have said is correct. In other words, the earlier we go ahead with MRT, the more money we will save. So we will leave it to the future and see what will happen.

    Sir, on the question of fare increases imposed by SBS, I would like to cite one Chinese saying. These are people who are prepared to chop off their head but there is nobody who is prepared to run a losing business. This is quite correct. So if the SBS is really running at a loss, then we should sympathize with it in its request to the Government to increase the bus fare by 10 cents all round.

    But I feel that SBS is not running at a loss. It is instead thinking of developing its business by purchasing more and bigger buses. Therefore, the company needs some capital to invest for their expansion and further development. If that is the case, then there is no reason for the SBS to increase the bus fares to raise the capital for its own business expansion. It is not right. It should not make its calculations at the expense of the passengers. That is not right.

    In my view, it is for the SBS to try and save money or to look for other sources of funds for its business expansion. Sir, I can say that Singapore Bus Service has a very bright future ahead. If the shareholders really feel that there is no future for the company, then a great many of them would have already sold their shares. At today's market price, the share value has gone up at least

Column: 1096

four-fold. If the company is losing money, how is it that the shareholders are still clinging on to their share certificates? This means that the company would have made sure of a profit of so many per cent per annum to itself. So if any fare increase is to be borne by the commuters, I think it is not right.

    If the Government allows the SBS to increase its bus fares, then the SBS should not be allowed to continue to enjoy its monopolistic position in the business. The Government should also allow either local people or interested foreign investors to run the bus services in Singapore for the benefit of the people here. In other words, if there are other organizations interested in providing public bus services, then the Government should issue licences to such organizations or people.

     The Chairman: Encik Saidi, since we are on public transport, you might as well speak on your amendment.

     Encik Saidi Shariff (Kaki Bukit): Sir, actually I am still writing out what I want to say. But, nevertheless, since I am called to speak, let me say a few things about the public transport system.

    Sir, the Programme Description on Public Transport states:

    'The planning and regulation of the public transport system including field studies, research and implementation of traffic management measures.' When we discuss the public transport system, we are referring to the whole network of roads with their directional signs and traffic lights that govern the operation of all public transport vehicles, such as buses and taxis, for the purpose of effective, speedy and safe mobility of people from one place to another.

    I am particularly interested to reflect in this House the situation of the public transport system in my constituency, particularly in the HDB estate of Bedok North. Anybody who connects to Bedok North - and I had the

Column: 1097

experience when I went there for the first time, by bus particularly - might have the nightmarish experience of finding his way round to his destination. It has been pointed out to me by many of my constituents that the feeder bus services are inadequate in terms of timing and frequency. So when I heard that the bus fare will be increased by five cents for the feeder bus service, I am very sure that I am going to face a lot of criticisms from my constituents. First of all, to pay 15 cents is a bit difficult. Probably it is better to retain the fare at 10 cents than to increase it to 15 cents. But, anyway, I am sure the Minister will say that the commuters will have to face the inconvenience of paying 15 cents.
3.00 p.m.

    What I want to raise particularly is in regard to the new Neighbourhoods 6 and 7. To me, I feel that the SBS is always thinking of making profits only. The SBS will respond to the request of the constituents only when it receives complaints that there is no service in the neighbourhood. It will first ask how many people are already residing in the neighbourhood. It is only when 80% of the people have moved into the neighbourhood, will the SBS start a bus service. I think that the SBS should be service-oriented in its profit-making venture. There is nothing wrong in making a profit but the first consideration is to provide a service.

    What I would like to know from the Ministry is that, if it is responsible for planning the transport system, then whenever a new housing estate is being developed, studies should be made as to how soon can a bus service be started. For instance, the Ministry should also find out how many buses are required and not to start a service only when there are complaints from the residents. At present there are not enough facilities at the Bedok bus interchange. I would like to invite Members here or even the Minister to go there, especially in the morning. I am sure they will find that they have to queue up for the bus. A lot of incon-

Column: 1098

venience is caused to the residents. I hope the Ministry can look into this matter and ensure that the bus system, particularly in the housing estate, is continually being improved.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I also take this opportunity to join in the debate. When I met my constituents and discussed about the Budget, some of the points, like those raised by the hon. Members for Khe Bong and Jurong, were also raised by my constituents.

    First, my constituents seem to have a very awkward feeling that the SBS is becoming and acting like a callous monopoly. Whether or not that is true, it is good for the Ministry to try and give some clarification.

    They also believe that the SBS is making a profit, because if it is not making a profit then the value of SBS shares must go down. In this regard, I was asked by my constituents whether, sometime in the future, I could ask the Minister to provide a more detailed statement of the profit and loss accounts of the SBS, taking into account the capital investments of the SBS over a specific number of years. They say this would help to clarify why in the case of the City Shuttle Bus Service they are able to operate with profits and without frequent increases in the bus fares. At the same time, it is also the first company to offer concessions to our senior citizens. Perhaps if the Minister could give more details about the profit and loss accounts of the SBS, then we would be in a better position to make an assessment on the viability of SBS, whether it is really making a profit, an unfair profit, against the interest of the commuters.

    I am confident that the SBS will find it more than an easy job to run an efficient service and, at the same time, make a profit and also avoid raising bus fares. This actually relates to the criteria of efficiency that we expect of a bus service. If we think that on the average 15 minutes' wait for a bus is fair, then I am sure the SBS would require a specific number of buses with a specific level

Column: 1099

of maintenance and repair service to maintain a flow of buses to meet the criteria of efficiency, that is, 15 minutes of waiting on the average for a bus service.

    It is not possible to maintain a very high standard of service if the SBS does not look for ways and means to raise the necessary funds. I am sure one of the ways is to increase the fares. I grant that it would be necessary for the SBS to increase the fares, but what I like the Minister to do is to give a clearer statement of the profit and loss of SBS. When there is a need to raise the bus fares, I would also like to ask the Minister whether he could also request the SBS to convince the public that it has taken all possible measures to reduce the cost of operations, administration and other costs which constitute part of the SBS cost of operation. Presumably, if the administration is more efficient, there will be more savings in manpower and so on. Any marginal increase in fuel cost can be met from savings in the administrative cost. Therefore, if the SBS can convince the public that it has taken all measures to save on administrative cost, and in spite of that, it still has to increase its fares, then please explain to the public. If this is done, I think it will be easier for us to understand why the SBS fares must be increased.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, let me tackle the MRT first. The Members for Punggol, Serangoon Gardens, Jurong and Khe Bong have asked when a decision on the MRT will be made, why delay it, and why spend further money on the various studies. As Members are aware, the Provisional Mass Rapid Transit Authority was set up in July last year to undertake all the preparatory works and studies related to the MRT. These works, which include traffic studies, soil investigations, land surveys and other detailed engineering work, have to be done before MRT construction can take place. That is to say, even if we make a decision today to proceed with the MRT, all these works will still have to be carried out before construction work can actually begin. In effect, what this means

Column: 1100

is that we are not delaying the project but rather preparing ourselves to proceed with the building of the MRT project with the minimum of delay once a decision is taken. I hope I have made this clear.

    The Provisional MRT Authority will be provided with $21 million for the next two to three years to carry out various preparatory work and studies. For 1981-82, $7 million have been provided. Of this sum, $5.6 million will go into the island-wide Comprehensive Traffic Study that the Provisional MRT Authority has just embarked upon. The remaining $1.4 million will be used for the engineering studies and land surveys to be carried out later this year.

    Members have asked the reasons for the delay in making a decision. As I have repeatedly explained in this House on many occasions before, Sir, the project is complex and very expensive with wide-ranging implications. This being the case, the decision to proceed with the MRT can only be taken after all factors have been carefully considered.

    In this connection, Sir, I would like to point out that transport considerations will feature quite prominently in helping us to arrive at that decision. The Comprehensive Traffic Study, which the Provisional MRT Authority has just commissioned, will determine how an all-bus system will fare in the years 1990 to 2000, i.e. whether it will be able to cope with the travel demand at that time. If it is found that an all-bus system cannot cope satisfactorily, the study will then proceed further to tell us at which point in time we should have the MRT.

    Sir, on transportation grounds alone, there is no justification to start building the MRT now if the buses could be made to cope until 1990, 1995 or 2000. Otherwise both the buses and the MRT system would be under-utilized. The advantage of stretching the bus system to cope for as long as we can is that we will be able to take advantage of the latest proven development in MRT technology, as well as learn from the mistakes of others. I do agree with the concern expressed by Members here that the longer we delay by

Column: 1101

procrastinating the decision the more it will cost us. But the other way is equally true. We will also be in a better position to afford the MRT at a later date than now. But that is not the key point. The main point is that if we can stretch the bus system as long as we can and defer the MRT till a later date, either three years or five years from now, then we will have the advantage of having the most up-to-date system, rather than to have one now which would be five years earlier and would be obsolete by the time we really need '
